processes.description: There is no lakes module in GC3.1.
There is no nitrogen cycling in GC3.1.
The surface and sub-surface runoff fluxes are supplied to an implementation of the TRIP river routing model.

citations.citationDetail: Oki T., and Y.C. Sud (1998) Design of the Total Runoff Integrating Pathways [TRIP] - A global river channel network.. Earth Interactions, 2.
citations.title: Design of the Total Runoff Integrating Pathways [TRIP] - A global river channel network
citations.collectiveTitle: Oki T., and Y.C. Sud (1998) Design of the Total Runoff Integrating Pathways [TRIP] - A global river channel network.. Earth Interactions, 2.

values: One way coupling surface and subsurface runoff into rivers.
Kinematic wave model with constant velocity.
Kinematic wave model with constant velocity.
Longitude, latitude grid 1.0 degrees in both directions.

subTopics.description: The river routing oceanic discharge is claculated by direct flow from major basins.
subTopics.overview: Oceanic discharge treatment in river routing

processes.description: Energy balance is resolved for each land-surface tile.

values: There is no tiling for the energy balance

processes.description: There is no carbon module in GC3.1.

subTopics.description: There is no representation of permafrost in GC3.1 beyond the fact that some soil layers may stay frozen year round.
subTopics.overview: Permafrost carbon treatment in carbon cycle

subTopics.description: Soil carbon is not a prognostic in the model. There is a fixed soil carbon map and one carbon pool.
Ther is no carbon cycle module in GC3.1.

propertySets.description: Autotrophic respiration treatment in carbon cycle
Vegetation mortality treatment in carbon cycle

subTopics.description: There is no litter module GC3.1.

processes.description: The snow module included is a layered snow module. A maximum number of layers is preset (three in this configuration) but layers are only created when the snow depth requires it. Variable density allows compaction of the snow pack. For needleleaf trees snow is partitioned between canopy interception and throughfall, with canopy snow being stored in a single reservoir.

There is no snow tiling in HadGEM3

processes.description: The vegetation coverage, LAI and height are prescribed by maps read from files and dynamic vegetation is turned off.

citations.citationDetail: Jacobs, C. M. J. Direct impact of atmospheric CO2 enrichment on regional transpiration PhD Thesis, Wageningen Agric. Univ., Wageningen, Netherlands
citations.title: Direct impact of atmospheric CO2 enrichment on regional transpiration
citations.collectiveTitle: Jacobs, C. M. J. Direct impact of atmospheric CO2 enrichment on regional transpiration PhD Thesis, Wageningen Agric. Univ., Wageningen, Netherlands

values: Stomatal resistance is dependant on photosynthesis rate, CO2 gradient across the leaf surface and the leaf humidity deficit. The stomatal conductance is related to photosynthesis by a diffusion equation. In addition an equation defined in Jacobs (1994) links this to leaf humidity deficit.
Seasonal climatology of vegetation parameters from files
Vegetation map is based on the IGBP land cover classes.

processes.description: The soil hydraulics in the model is an implementation of the van Genuchten equations.

citations.citationDetail: van Genuchten, M. Th (1980) A closed-form equation for predicting the hydraulic conductivity of unsaturated soils Soil Science Society of America Journal, 44:892–898
citations.title: A closed-form equation for predicting the hydraulic conductivity of unsaturated soils
citations.collectiveTitle: van Genuchten, M. Th (1980) A closed-form equation for predicting the hydraulic conductivity of unsaturated soils Soil Science Society of America Journal, 44:892–898

values: Darcy / Richardson for soil moisture. Simplified Johanson method for energy and TOPMODEL for deep layer water.

There is a soft coupling.The temperature of a given soil layer is incremented by the diffusive heat fluxes into and out of the layer and the advective flux from the layer by flowing water. The thermal conductivity is dependent on the soil moisture in a given layer.
Soil temperature, soil moisture, moisture in deep layer

subTopics.description: Incoming precipitation is divided between canopy intercepted and throughfall. Throughfall at a rate lower than a (hydraulic conductivity based) threshold infiltrates the soil. Surplus is partitioned into surface runoff. Movement of moisture between soil layers is based on the hydraulic relationships of van Genuchten.
subTopics.overview: Key properties of the soil hydrology

values: Soil water may freeze with the amount dependent on the minimisation of Gibbs free energy.
Four soil layers at 0.1 m, 0.35 m, 0.65 m and 2.0 m depth.

subTopics.description: Heat treatment within surface / soil is a simplified version of the scheme described in Johansen (1975) and is documented in Dharssi et al. (2009). Heat fluxes take into account frozen and unfrozen components of soil moisture.

values: Four layers at 0.1 m, 0.25 m, 0.65 m and 2.0 m depth.

subTopics.description: The soil map is derived from the Harmonized World Soil Database (HWSD) and the hydraulic parameters are derived from the texture properties and equations from Brookes Corey. The hydraulic and thermal parameters are derived from the grid box mean ratios of sand, silt and clay.
subTopics.overview: Key properties of the land surface soil map

values: The soil texture map  is the Harmonized World Soil Database (HWSD).
Organic matter is not used to derive the thermal or hydraulic properties.
Soil depth is a constant 3.0 m.

subTopics.description:
Snow free albedo is calculated as the fraction area covered weight sum of individual tile albedos, with lake and urban albedo taking a globally prescribed value, soil albedo prescribed from a soil colour map (Best et al., 2011).

Vegetated tile albedo are calculated based on radiative transfer through vegetation as described by Sellers (1985) and implemented by Essery et al. (2001). This scheme uses separate direct-beam and diffuse albedos in the visible and near-infrared for each vegetation type and requires four parameter values for leaf reflection and leaf scattering coefficients for both near-infrared and photosynthetically active radiation. Beams are intercepted/scattered through the canopy, where leaves are approximated as isotropic scattering elements. A fraction of both beams penetrate the canopy and is reflected by the bare soils prescribed albedo.

grid.description: The land-surface grid maps to the atmospheric model grid.

subTopics.description: Horizontal grid matches the atmospheric model grid.
subTopics.overview: The horizontal grid in the land surface

subTopics.description: The total depth of the soil is 3 m with the vertical grid structured as four layers for water and energy at 0.1, 0.25, 0.65 and 2.0 m.
subTopics.overview: The vertical grid in the soil

values: Four soil layers for water and energy at 0.1, 0.25, 0.65, 2.0 m.

keyProperties.description: Covers the key properties of the model including its details, processes modelled, flux exchanges, atmospheric coupling treatment, land cover types, tiling, conservation properties, software properties and timestepping framework.

values: There are nine tiles: five plant functional types and four non-vegetated tiles. Land-sea is defined from the atmospheric component. Vegetation is static.
Prognostic albedo, canopy interception, soil hydrology, photosynthesis, surface energy and water exchange.

subTopics.description: Energy conservation has been assessed as part of the coupled model configuration development process.
Land-surface is called during each atmospheric timestep (1200s in GC3.1).
Details of the software properties for the model, including repository, version and coding language.
subTopics.overview: Software properties of land surface code

values:
Atmosphere-land component model was tuned to reduce key errors deemed
critical to model stakeholders, such as S. Ocean surface temperature bias, or
tropical tropopause temperature errors, while maintaining performance
against a basket of ~100 other process-based and top-down metrics. An
approximate net downward TOA radiation of +/- 0.5 Wm-2 under pre-
industrial forcing was targeted, to increase the likelihood of the TOA being far
from balance when coupled to the ocean. See Walters et al (2017) and
Williams et al (2017) for the general approach taken to evaluation and tuning,
and Mulcahy et al (2018) for specific changes made to ensure a realistic
aerosol forcing.

description: Land-surface component of HadGEM3 GC3.1. The joint UK Land Environment Simulator (JULES) model is based on the Met Office Surface Exchange Scheme (MOSES). Sub-grid scale surface heterogeneity is represented by a tiling system. A multi-layer snow scheme has been implemented since HadGEM2.
